head.title: An Ode to the Book, a Thing of Beauty

hedline.hl1: An Ode to the Book, a Thing of Beauty

abstract.p: David Masello letter comments on May 22 Business Day article on E-books (S)

block.p: Re ''Updating a Paperback Heroine: Can Mary Higgins Clark Lure Her Faithful to E-Books?'' (Business Day, May 22):
Re ''Updating a Paperback Heroine: Can Mary Higgins Clark Lure Her Faithful to E-Books?'' (Business Day, May 22):

Jack Romanos, president and chief operating officer of Simon & Schuster, is quoted in your article as referring to a book as a ''container'' for words. His remark discounts the book as an object of value and beauty in itself.
Nobody, not even Mr. Romanos, knows yet the fate of books, though he is emphatic about his desire in the next few years ''to try to reach readers on a screen, not in a book.''
For many people, a significant part of the experience of reading remains tactile, as well as visual.
As a major publisher, Mr. Romanos should care about the state of the book as an object and everyone involved in its making, including designers, illustrators, printers and editors.
There are still more of us who prefer printed words on paper to electronic impulses on the screen.
